metadata.case_name: Dattatraya Gurunath v. Kalasappa and others

facts.text: Dyamappa had sons Kalasappa, Girimaji, Krishtarao, Hanamanta.
Krishtarao died in 1890, leaving surviving two widows Radhabai (senior) and Gangabai (junior) and a son Dattatraya.
Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving surviving a widow Sundarabai and a son Jagannath.
Gangabai adopted the plaintiff Dattatraya Gurunath in 1943.

Appellant instituted suit on 15th March 1944 in forma pauperis claiming to be adopted son of Krishtarao by Gangabai, entitled to possession of adoptive father's properties and declaration re compensation money.
Defendants (sons and grandsons of first cousin of Krishtarao) disputed plaintiff's adoption on ground that Gangabai's power extinguished when Dattatraya died in 1913 leaving widow and son.
Gangabai in written statement supported plaintiff's claim and asserted Radhabai gave consent to adoption.
Trial judge upheld defendants' contention, dismissed suit; upheld factum of adoption but held Radhabai did not give consent.
High Court affirmed trial court decision, held Gangabai's power to adopt ended when her son died leaving son and widow; no finding on Radhabai's consent.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave in forma pauperis.

legal_issues.text: Whether a widow can exercise a power of adoption conferred on her or possessed by her at any time during her life irrespective of any devolution of property or changes in the family or other circumstances and even after a grandson has come on the scene but has subsequently died without leaving a widow or a son.

petitioner_arguments.text: Hindu Shastric Law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the widow's power of adoption once she has acquired that power or is possessed of it, and the power can be exercised by her during her life-time when necessity arises for the purpose of continuing the line of her husband.

Power suspended during son's lifetime revives on son dying sonless and unmarried; logically revives when son, widow, grandson and his widow all die out; substitution for spiritual reasons essence, devolution of property accessory.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Amarendra Mansingh v. Sanatan (1933 L.R. 60 I.A. 242)

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule in Amarendra's case has no application; power revives on death of grandson; cites Bapuji v. Gangaram and Prem Jagat Kuer v. Harihar Bakhsh Singh.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bapuji v. Gangaram (1941 I.L.R. Nagpur 178); Prem Jagat Kuer v. Harihar Bakhsh Singh (1945 I.L.R. 21 Luck. 1)

respondent_arguments.text: Though Hindu Shastric Law sets no limit, judicially recognised that power is not unlimited and absolute, comes to an end when another heir has come on the scene and passed on duty of continuing the line.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Chundrabullee cases and subsequent Privy Council decisions

court_reasoning.text: Reviews Privy Council decisions starting from Bhoobun Moyee v. Ram Kishore (1865) and Padma Coomari (1881), holding power incapable after son leaves widow as heir with vested estate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power at end upon vesting of estate in son's widow.

court_reasoning.text: Affirms rule in Thayammal (1887), Tarachurn (1889), Ramkrishna Ramchandra (1902 Bom), Madana Mohana (1918), where power extinguished when son dies leaving son or widow competent to continue line.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power once extinguished cannot be revived.

court_reasoning.text: In Amarendra Mansingh (1933), reorients to spiritual aspect: power ends with interposition of grandson or son's widow competent to continue line; not mere birth of son; not dependent on property vesting.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty passed to grandson or son's widow ends mother's power.

court_reasoning.text: Rule reaffirmed in Vijaysingji (1935), Anant Bhikappa (1943); consistent for three quarters century; courts can lay down on justice, equity; no grounds to depart.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Too late to question limitations on widow's power.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects revival argument: if duty passed to grandson, cannot revive; distinguishes cases where son dies incompetent without widow/son.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Moment son hands torch to another, mother cannot take it.

court_reasoning.text: Nagpur and Lucknow High Court decisions erroneous, misread Amarendra.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No revival on son's widow remarriage or grandson's death.

holdings.text: Widow's power to make an adoption comes to an end by the interposition of a grandson or the son's widow competent to continue the line by adoption; once extinguished, cannot revive.

precedents_cited.relevance: Power incapable after son marries and leaves widow as heir with vested estate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Padma Coomari v. Court of Wards
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirms power ends upon vesting in widow of son.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thayammal and Kuttiswami Aiyan v. Venkatarama Aiyan

precedents_cited.relevance: Power extinguished when son dies leaving widow to continue line; cannot revive.
Approves Bombay Full Bench: power ends when son dies after attaining capacity, leaving line continuer.
Power ends with interposition of grandson or son's widow; spiritual duty basis, not property.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil
Shrinivas Krishnarao Kango v. Narayan Devji Kango
precedents_cited.relevance: One proposition accepted, no doubt cast on rule.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prem Jagat Kuer v. Harihar Bakhsh Singh

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; adoption by Gangabai in 1943 held invalid as her power to adopt extinguished in 1913 when son Dattatraya died leaving son Jagannath and widow Sundarabai competent to continue the line.

key_quotes.text: Hindu law itself sets no limit to the exercise of the power during the lifetime of the widow and the validity of successive adoptions in continuance of the line is now well recognised.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Acknowledges no Shastric limit but upholds judicial limits.

key_quotes.text: Where the duty of providing for the continuance of the line for spiritual purposes which was upon the father, and was laid by him conditionally upon the mother, has been assumed by the son and by him passed on to a grandson or to the son's widow, the mother's power is gone.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle from Amarendra explaining extinction of power.

key_quotes.text: The power having once been extinguished it cannot afterwards be revived.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects revival argument central to case.
